properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for a brief but intense snow squall as a fast moving cold front passes this afternoon. The snow squall is expected to extend from Winisk River Provincial Park to Weagamow Lake to Deer Lake late this afternoon and move southeastward. The line is expected to reach Ogoki to Pickle Lake around midnight. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T06:16:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-11T14:17:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2193956244.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of heavy snow may affect the morning commute on Wednesday. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locations: All of Nova Scotia except for the Tri-counties. Time span: overnight into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Rain has begun over southwestern Nova Scotia and periods of snow will spread eastward across the remainder of the province this evening. Precipitation will taper to scattered of flurries or showers later this evening. A swath of heavy snow is expected to redevelop across much of the province overnight, potentially giving snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm in just a few hours before the snow ends on Wednesday morning. Reduced visibility in rapidly accumulating snow could have impacts on the morning commute in many parts of the province early Wednesday morning. In addition, recent forecast guidance indicates that another system will bring more snow to most of the province on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T11:47:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-11T19:48:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0744392910.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor weather expected on Wednesday. A sharp cold front will sweep across Northwestern Quebec on Wednesday. It will cross Waskaganish in the morning, Matagami in the afternoon, then the Chibougamau, the Abitibi, and the Temiscamingue areas late in the day or in the evening. Intense flurries and strong winds are expected with this front, giving momentarily near zero visibilities under the snow and in the blowing snow. Moreover, rapidly falling temperatures are on tap behind the cold front, which could make some roads icy and slippery. The intense cold will stall Wednesday overnight, and wind chill values between minus 35 and minus 40 are possible Thursday morning. Driving conditions may be hazardous at times in these areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T09:00:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-11T17:01:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2705540314.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A bitterly cold airmass with temperatures near minus 40 and moderate northwest winds are producing extreme wind chills in the -55 to -60 range. Wind chills will moderate into the -40 to -55 range overnight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T09:14:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-11T17:15:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0830297826.2020
Area: Baker Lake, Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of heavy snow may affect the morning commute on Wednesday. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locations: All of Nova Scotia except for the South Shore and the western half of the Annapolis Valley. Time span: overnight into Wednesday morning. Remarks: A disturbance tracking south of the province will spread periods of snow to the province later today, changing to or mixing with rain over southwestern sections of the province this evening before tapering to a chance of flurries in most areas late this evening. As this system begins to pull away from the region late tonight, a swath of heavy snow is expected to develop across much of the province overnight, potentially giving snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm in just a few hours before the snow ends on Wednesday morning. These snowfall rates and rapidly accumulating snow could have impacts on the morning commute in many parts of the province early Wednesday morning. In addition, recent forecast guidance indicates that another system will bring more snow to most of the province on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T06:49:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-11T14:50:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2456426728.2020

properties.Title: Weather Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy bands of snow are moving through central Alberta, including the Edmonton Metro today. Visibility will be greatly reduced while under these bands, in some cases to less than 500 m and snow will accumulate quickly. Overall snowfall amounts will likely approach 10-15 cm, however the bulk of that snow has already fallen and the low visibility is the main hazard at this time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to persist until tonight. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-12T16:59:59-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system crossing from northern BC into Alberta border is giving snow to northeast BC. 8 cm of snow has fallen so far at the Fort Nelson airport with this system, and another 2 to 5 cm cm is expected before the snow tapers off this afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind chill values in the -45 to -55 range will spread southwards across northern Manitoba today. Temperatures of -30 to -35°C will expand southwards into the Lynn Lake, Thompson, and Gillam areas today as an Arctic air mass builds into the region. Combined with northerly winds of 20 to 30 km/h, dangerous wind chill will develop with values in the -45 to -55 range. Extreme wind chills will spread through most of the remainder of Manitoba tonight into Wednesday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total Snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locations: Eastern Newfoundland from Gander to Clarenville. Time span: Wednesday afternoon and evening. Remarks: Fresh fallen snow will combine with increasing northwesterly winds gusting between 60 and 80 km/h to reduce visibility in blowing snow. Conditions will improve over most areas by late Wednesday evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Dangerous wind chill values in the -45 to -55 range are expected tonight. Wind chill values will dip to the -45 to -50 range again Wednesday night. Regions closer to Hudson Bay may reach the -45 to -50 range Thursday night. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system crossing northern BC is giving snow to the Williston region including Highway 97 - Pine Pass, McGregor, and Yellowhead. The snow will ease this afternoon as the low moves southeastward and into Alberta. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
